title: Fast and efficient synaptosome isolation and post-synaptic density enrichment from hiPSC-motor neurons by biochemical sub-cellular fractionation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
The protocol provided below is described for one hiPSC-MN cell line plated on one full 6-well plate (for fewer number of wells per 6-well plate, see troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]). A schematic representation of the protocol is provided in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2397-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Step-by-step scheme of the protocol
The labels for the 1.5 mL centrifuge tubes are shown in red font, whereas the notations of the different sub-cellular fractions and their respective instructions are shown in either blue or black font.
Note: Take into consideration that the timing for the various steps will be delayed incrementally depending on the number of cell lines and/or plates simultaneously used (See troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]).
Critical: All steps are to be performed on ice.
Isolation of synaptosomes
Timing: 30 min
The first part of the protocol involves the preparation of the total homogenate of the MNs by mechanical disruption. Then the total lysate is purified from the cell debris, nuclei and the extracellular matrix by centrifugation. Upon further centrifugation, the cytosol is obtained in the supernatant, and the crude synaptosomal fraction is extracted from the pellet.
Note: Always start with one 6-well plate.
Washing the cells.
Completely aspirate the cell culture medium from all wells.
Quickly wash twice with 500 μL of DPBS per well.
Homogenate (Ho) preparation.
Distribute a total of 1 mL of Buffer A to all wells of the 6-well plate.
Use a cell scraper to collect the cells from all the wells and transfer them to a glass douncer.
Homogenize manually for 30 strokes and transfer the homogenate (Ho) to the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “P.”
Collect 100 μL separately in the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “Ho.”
Lysate (S1) preparation.

Centrifuge the remaining Ho in tube “P” at 500 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant containing the lysate (S1) to the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “P3.”
Critical: Due to the softness of the pellet, please proceed cautiously without disturbing it when collecting the supernatant (see troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]).
Note: The supernatant is transferred to the P3 tube because after each subsequent centrifugation the pellet remains in this same tube until the last step when the actual P3 fraction is obtained.
Collect 100 μL separately in the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “S1.”
Note: The pellet (P1) remaining in tube “P” (containing the cell debris, nuclei and extracellular matrix) can be discarded.
Synaptosome (P2) isolation.
Centrifuge the P3 tube containing the remaining lysate at 10,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant containing the cytosol (S2) to the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “S2.”
Resuspend the pellet completely in 200 μL of Buffer B to obtain the crude synaptosomal fraction (P2).
Transfer 50 μL separately to the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “P2.”
Enrichment of post-synaptic density (PSD)
Timing: 1 h 30 min
The second part of the protocol involves a further centrifugation step that separates the synaptic cytosol in the supernatant from the PSD fraction in the pellet.
Separation of synaptic cytosol fraction (S3).
Centrifuge the remaining P2 at 20,000 × g for 80 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant containing the synaptic cytosol fraction (S3) to the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “S3.”
Enrichment of PSD fraction (P3).
Completely resuspend the pellet (remaining in the 1.5 mL centrifuge tube labeled “P3”) in 70 μL of Buffer C to obtain the enriched PSD fraction (P3) (see troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).
Estimation of protein concentration and storage.

Estimate the protein concentrations of the Ho, S1, S2, P2, S3 and P3 fractions (see troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Snap freeze the samples in liquid nitrogen and store them at –80°C up to 1 year.
Note: The fractions can also be stored as smaller aliquots in order to avoid repeated freeze-thaw cycles.
